title: How to Cut a Pixie Cut

steps.headline: Start with damp hair that is already cut to at least shoulder-length.
steps.description: Starting with hair that is already cut somewhat short will be a lot easier to work with than long hair. If the client's hair falls past their shoulders, gather their hair into a ponytail, then cut it off. This is known as rough-cutting, and will make the length more manageable. Don't worry if it looks uneven. You will continue to take off more length in the following steps and even things out some more. Don't cut too close to the person's head. The ponytail will make the cut hair easier to manage, as it will stay tied together. Also, it gives the client the option to donate the hair.

steps.headline: Refine the hairline along the nape.
steps.description: Pull a comb through the hairline, pulling it up. Placing your fingers just behind the comb, make a V-shape with your fore and middle fingers, closing them against the hair at the nape. Then, cut the hair just below them. Repeat the process along the hairline, holding your fingers at a slight angle. Work with a thin section of hair, no longer than the length of your first knuckle to your second knuckle on your finger. If you are cutting curly hair, plan on cutting it 1½ to 2 inches (3.81 to 5.08 centimeters) long.

steps.headline: Separate the front part of the hair from the back.
steps.description: Use the handle of a rat-tail comb to create a vertical part on each side of the head, just behind the ears. Each part should meet on the top of your head. Brush the hair in front of the ear forward, out of the way. If the hair won't stay forward, secure it with clips.

steps.headline: Cut a vertical section of hair on the back-center of the head.
steps.description: Take a vertical section of hair from the back-center of the client's head, comb through it, and pinch it between your fore and middle fingers. Slide your fingers down to where you want to cut, then snip the hairs sticking out in front of your fingers. Pixie cuts are short—no longer than 2 inches (5.08 centimeters).

steps.headline: Cut a horizontal section of hair across the vertical one.
steps.description: Pinch a horizontal of hair, right across the section you just cut. Slide your fingers down until you see the cut ends of the vertical section. Cut the horizontal section so that it aligns with the vertical one.

steps.headline: Continue to cut the hair in vertical and horizontal sections.
steps.description: Work your way towards the right side of the head, then repeat for the left side. Keep alternating between vertical and horizontal sections. This technique will allow you to measure up the already-cut strands against the un-cut strands. Stop when you get to the vertical parts just behind the ears.

steps.headline: Blend the hair by combing it upwards and snipping it.
steps.description: Comb the hair upwards with a fine-toothed comb. Snip the hair that's sticking out through the bristles as you comb upward. Create a soft, round line that follows the curve of the client's head. You won't cut everything that's in front of the comb, which is the point. You should only remove small quantities of hair at this time. If you realize you have a lot of hair to cut, then you should recut using the techniques discussed above, then try blending again.

steps.headline: Cut the hair on the sides using the same technique a you did for the back.
steps.description: Pinch thin, vertical and horizontal sections of hair between your fore and middle fingers, then snip them with the hairdressing shears. Do one side first, then the other. Pinch some of the cut strand against the un-cut strands so that you know how much to cut off. To make sure the sides are even, pull the hair on both sides straight out, then visually compare them in the mirror.

steps.headline: Feather the hair around the ear.
steps.description: Comb the hair downwards, over the ears. Carefully cut into the hair around the ears, pointing the shears upwards. Use the natural hairline around the ears as a guide. Work your way back-to-front, then front-to-back.

steps.headline: Consider doing an undercut for a twist.
steps.description: Begin by combing the hair on the back upward, then cutting whatever is sticking out of the comb. Work your way across the back and along the sizes. Finish off by pulling the hair away from the head with a comb, then going over it with a buzzer. Finish off the undercut by buzzing around the hairline along the nape and ears. If you are doing an undercut, consider blow drying the hair straight first.

steps.headline: Cut the top part of the hair.
steps.description: Pinch a vertical section of hair between your fore and middle fingers. Include a few cut strands from the back, and angle your fingers outward, away from your head. Cut the hair sticking out of the fingers. How much you angle your fingers depends on how long you want the top to be. The further you angle your fingers upwards, the longer the top will be.

steps.headline: Continue cutting the top, blending it into the back and sides.
steps.description: Work your way across the back of the crown, using the same angling technique as before. Use the same technique when you do the sides. If you have any hair left over on the top, measure it up against the already-cut strands on the tip of the angles. For the top of the head, gather the hair parallel to the hair line and cut straight across. Then, you need to check the hair on the top of the head against the other sections and the sides of the head. If you don't cut enough from the top, then you could end up with a mushroom shape. Leave the bangs alone for now. He has been a hairstylist for over 25 years and is a Thermal Reconditioning Specialist, dedicated to transforming difficult curls and waves into sleek, straight hair. Patrick Evan Salon was rated the Best Hair Salon in San Francisco by Allure magazine, and Patrick's work has been featured in Woman’s Day, The Examiner, and 7x7. Patrick Evan			Owner, Patrick Evan Salon				Make sure your cut is balanced. Patrick Evan Salon owner, Patrick Evan, explains: "Head shape is incredibly important. If your head is a bit cone shaped, for example, the cut has to be done will a bit more fullness in the corners to make sure the shape is balanced out into an oval."

steps.headline: Comb the bangs forward, then cut them to the length you want.
steps.description: Pinch a section of hair between your fore and middle fingers. Slide your fingers down to where you want to cut (ie: jut below the eyes), then cut the hair below the fingers. Work your way across the bangs, from one side to the other. Remember that the hair will shrink up when it dries, so be careful when you cut the bangs. Leave the bangs longer than the desired length, as you can trim them after the hair dries if they are too long. Measure the un-cut strands against the already-cut strands.

steps.headline: Blend the bangs into the top part of your hair.
steps.description: Pinch a vertical section of the bangs between your fore and middle finger. Pull the hair upwards and measure it against the already cut strands on the top of the head. Angle your fingers, then cut the hair that's sticking out of them. Work your way from one side of the bangs to the other. Angle your fingers down into the bangs. This way, the hairs on the top of the bangs will blend into the hairs on the top of your head.

steps.headline: Consider thinning the hair along the top and bangs.
steps.description: Pull a thin strand of hair upwards, then gently glide the scissors along the shaft, making short, tiny snips. Repeat this technique wherever you think the hair should be thinned (typically along the top and bangs). This technique works especially well for undercut pixies. Blend the thinning by pinching the strand between your fore and middle fingers, then cutting upwards into the hair with the scissors.

steps.headline: Comb, dry, and style the hair, as desired.
steps.description: Pixie hair is fun and cheeky, so a simply blow-dry is all most people will need. You can spike the hair further with a little bit of hair wax or pomade. Check the hair after you've styled it. If necessary, you can trim areas that are too long.
